subject: Re: [junit] Re: What's wrong with using inner classes for tests?
msgSnippet: ... Hash: SHA1 Hi Jason, ... Well, basically I wouldn t have cared until someone tried to sell a false statement as the only valid truth. And I think those
messageBody:
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi Jason,

Am Donnerstag, 10. April 2003 18:34 schrieb Jason Rogers:
> On Thu, 2003-04-10 at 12:05, Herr Christian Wolfgang Hujer wrote:
>
> [snip a lot of rhetoric]
>
> So... we are debating semantics. From a specification standpoint it
> doesn't exist. From a readable code standpoint, it does.
>
> public class A {
> private static class B {
> }
> }
>
> It's a definition of a static class inside another class. Who cares
> what you call it? ;)
Well, basically I wouldn't have cared until someone tried to sell a false
statement as the only valid truth.

And I think those doing certifications care ;-)

I think the list is also read by some of the poor guys wanting to get
certified. If we use the wrong terms (still knowing what we're talking of),
we're confusing them even more.

It's not too difficult to use the term "nested" instead of "inner".

If you wanna say I should have chosen less harsh words, you're right. I was
just too boiled up. Next time I'll try to keep calm. Thanks for your
reminder.


Bye
- --
